metadata.synopsis: Ettvard Needle is the editor of the Baldur's Mouth Gazette. He is proudly pro-Gortash, obnoxious towards the PC, and insinuates (wel, directly states at the moment)  that the gazette is about to print a hit piece about the players.Players can intimidate Ettvard for some info, or use blackmail on him if they have found it to keep the hit piece from being published.
metadata.how_to_trigger: Talk to Ettvard in the main room of the Baldurs Mouth building.

7.speaker: Ettvard Needle
7.text: Hah! Caught you! Bet you thought you were so clever sneaking back in... GUARDS!

17.speaker: Ettvard Needle
17.text: Lord Gortash is going to destroy me. I swear, you'll rue the day you crossed Ettvard Needle.

23.speaker: Ettvard Needle
23.text: I know you meddled with my printing press. I know you published that fluff piece about yourself.

95.speaker: Ettvard Needle
95.text: And I also know it doesn't matter. Sure, some will read it - but you're no dead duke. You're old news. To be forgotten.

42.speaker: Ettvard Needle
42.text: How is one meant to cover a dead duke with an equally dead printing press...? Simply can't supply the demand...
42.context: NodeContext: muttering to self, clearly very stressed ignoring player

44.speaker: Ettvard Needle
44.text: Well, well, if it isn't the city's next celebrity! You star in our next edition's top story.

107.speaker: Player
107.text: I did, until I swapped out the articles. You'll smear me no more.

15.speaker: Player
15.text: Seems odd you've written the article before asking me any questions.

62.speaker: Ettvard Needle
62.text: Estra deals with the personal interviews and fluff pieces. I deal with the truth. And the truth is - you're a damned menace.

72.speaker: Player
72.text: Yeah - I heard all about your article, and I want you to shut it down.

80.speaker: Ettvard Needle
80.text: Ettvard Needle. Editor of the Baldur's Mouth Gazette. Speaking truth to power since 1450 DR.

65.speaker: Ettvard Needle
65.text: No need to introduce yourself. I make sure I become intimately familiar with my subjects before writing about them.

32.speaker: Player
32.text: Are you sure you have enough ink to cover all my adventures?

40.speaker: Ettvard Needle
40.text: We have plenty of ink. Enough to cover all your misadventures in this good city.

96.speaker: Ettvard Needle
96.text: Trafficking refugees into our city is hardly a good look. Especially when so many are Absolutists and murderers.

11.speaker: Ettvard Needle
11.text: Not many enter our fine city and immediately start meddling in murder investigations. Curious, don't you think?

39.speaker: Ettvard Needle
39.text: I've never heard of so much violence against innocent circus freaks before.

1.speaker: Ettvard Needle
1.text: I heard you may be affiliated with the arsonists who destroyed our Steel Watch protectors.

99.speaker: Ettvard Needle
99.text: The truth will be out with tomorrow's broadsheet. People will spit in your face. Your very presence will be bad for business. You'll be a pariah. An outcast. As you should be.

49.speaker: Ettvard Needle
49.text: And then we can only hope the Fist do their duty and escort you to the gallows! Your days scumming up this good city's streets will be over.

87.speaker: Player
87.text: I'd be terrified if I hadn't changed the article already.

24.speaker: Ettvard Needle
24.text: Shall I add 'lying cretin' to your long list of misdeeds? You speak nonsense.

38.speaker: Player
38.text: I'm working with Lord Gortash. He wouldn't want bad rumours spread about me.

27.speaker: Ettvard Needle
27.text: Nice try - but it's not going to work. Lord Gortash and me are very close and he mentioned no such thing to me.

29.speaker: Player
29.text: This letter proving you're Gortash's puppet would make a better headline.

56.speaker: Ettvard Needle
56.text: Pray tell - how exactly will you disseminate that information? What's the name of your highly popular broadsheet? No? Exactly.

86.speaker: Ettvard Needle
86.text: I would never reveal my sources, and certainly not to the likes of you. Besides, you're too late.

4.speaker: Player
4.text: Perhaps a bit of coin could make the article go away?

20.speaker: Ettvard Needle
20.text: You'd like me to add bribery to your list of extra-legal pursuits? How bold.

92.speaker: Player
92.text: If what you've just said is true, pissing me off is a bad idea. Stop the article.

97.speaker: Player
97.text: First I will break your printer. Then I will break YOU. STOP THE ARTICLE.

22.speaker: Player
22.text: It'll be your word against mine - and I'm really good with words.

26.speaker: Player
26.text: Stop the article, or I'll cook you from the inside out.

3.speaker: Ettvard Needle
3.text: I'm not afraid of you. Lord Gortash is a passionate champion of the journalistic arts - attack me, and you face the Steel Watch.

98.speaker: Ettvard Needle
98.text: The headlines are loaded into the printworks already. Tomorrow you will feel the power of free speech. Vox populi, vox dei.

18.speaker: Player
18.text: Print that about me and I'll push your corpse through the Gazette printworks.

8.speaker: Player
8.text: You know I've done far, far worse than that, right?

30.speaker: Ettvard Needle
30.text: ...Oh, really? I'm all ears, my quill dipped, dunked, and ready to tell the world whatever you wish to confess.

53.speaker: Player
53.text: Imagine a chronicle of your deeds, written in bile on the skin of fools.

100.speaker: Narrator
100.text: *Your tongue slithers over your glory like the snake it is, tasting each misdeed once again.*
100.context: CinematicNodeContext: DARK URGE GRINS - DARK URGE RAGE GRAPHIC PLAYS

105.speaker: Ettvard Needle
105.text: Gods, the untold depravity... it is unprintable. I'll be out of syndication if I publish your gore-smut confessional.
105.context: CinematicNodeContext: When the dark urge leaves the frenzy of their imagination, Ettvard is shocked.

69.speaker: Ettvard Needle
69.text: We will stick to our existing story, and you're fortunate that's all.

6.speaker: Ettvard Needle
6.text: Now, GUARDS! I believe our distinguished guest was just leaving. Would you care to escort them out?

78.speaker: Player
78.text: Let the guards take you outside.

102.speaker: Player
102.text: Bite your tongue. Grant them mercy from your horrible tale.

93.speaker: Narrator
93.text: *With great difficulty, you throw aside the desire to toot your own terror-trumpet for this smut-peddler.*

83.speaker: Ettvard Needle
83.text: Oh, I know plenty about you already, knave.

76.speaker: Ettvard Needle
76.text: Since your arrival, reports of Absolutist activity in this city have increased tenfold. Hardly seems a coincidence.

47.speaker: Player
47.text: How long is this article? Because I've got a lot of stories - and I only blow up in some of them.

37.speaker: Player
37.text: I have more than stories - ballads, prose, even a haiku or two, if you can spare the ink.

57.speaker: Player
57.text: How long is this article? I'd love to publish some of my own magical theories.

63.speaker: Player
63.text: I'd rather your paper focus on more pressing things - like this city, and how it squanders nature's gifts.

82.speaker: Player
82.text: How about a piece on siege tactics? Or self-defence? I have plenty of suggestions.

85.speaker: Player
85.text: I might have to check in with my patron about that first - see how they feel about being in the spotlight.

106.speaker: Player
106.text: I have no need of such attention. I suggest you focus on something useful - like the obvious corruption in this city.

13.speaker: Player
13.text: I'd rather you spread the word about the one I serve. I have some suggestions, if you'd like.

0.speaker: Player
0.text: My prowess in battle does the talking for me - I have no need of your 'stories'.

41.speaker: Ettvard Needle
41.text: Well, you should've considered that before disgracing yourself in public.

14.speaker: Player
14.text: I'd rather not be in your paper at all. Anonymity is helpful in my... business.

89.speaker: Player
89.text: I'd rather not be in your paper at all.

94.speaker: Ettvard Needle
94.text: Suit yourself - be sure to have a gander at tomorrow's edition - you star.

81.speaker: Ettvard Needle
81.text: The guards will see you out.

59.speaker: Ettvard Needle
59.text: You again. Old news - I've got a dead duke to commemorate. Be on your way.

64.speaker: Ettvard Needle
64.text: Say - I know that face. We had an absolute blinder of a piece ready to print about you. Would've been your ruin, I reckon.

2.speaker: Ettvard Needle
2.text: But alas. Any articles not about Gortash's death might as well be bog roll at the moment.
2.context: NodeContext: a bit more to himself, he's ignoring the player thinking about the articles he's comissioning

51.speaker: Player
51.text: If anything bad is printed about me, I'll leak this letter to you from Lord Gortash.

90.speaker: Player
90.text: Why were you writing something negative about me?

35.speaker: Ettvard Needle
35.text: Oh, you gave us plenty to work with.

84.speaker: Ettvard Needle
84.text: However, column space is a rare commodity when a lord dies. So you can consider the tales of your misdeeds indefinitely postponed.

101.speaker: Ettvard Needle
101.text: Now, take your leave. I have so many articles to arrange for the next edition - dead men might tell no tales, but they certainly sell them.

45.speaker: Player
45.text: If anything bad is printed about me, your obituary will follow soon after.

79.speaker: Ettvard Needle
79.text: You think I'd dedicate precious column space to a miscreant like you when a lord's just died? Do get a grip.

21.speaker: Player
21.text: A shame it was never published - I always wanted to be in a broadsheet.

71.speaker: Ettvard Needle
71.text: That's the spirit - better people spit your name than not say it at all.

73.speaker: Ettvard Needle
73.text: If you think bothering me will delay your article being published, you're quite deluded.

34.speaker: Player
34.text: Would these blackmail letters from Gortash delay publication?

88.speaker: Ettvard Needle
88.text: We can still publish, but Gortash'll have my hide if I don't fix the printworks - You! Get out of here, I'm busy!
88.context: NodeContext: muttering to self, then notices the player after hyphen
